summary: This document is a chronological timeline detailing events in the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) surrounding Jeffrey Epstein's incarceration, his interactions with cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione, the discovery of a note left by Epstein, and subsequent legal and media activities. It covers the period from Epstein's booking to post-mortem investigations and media reports.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure in the case, incarcerated at MCC. Found unresponsive in his cell on July 23, 2019, and later found dead on August 10, 2019. Allegedly left a note for his cellmate.

persons.name: Nicholas Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate at MCC. Found a note allegedly left by Epstein in a book. Claimed Epstein assaulted him, which Epstein denied.

persons.name: Stemheim
persons.context: An official appointed on August 21, 2019, likely to investigate prison conditions or Epstein's death. Produced a report.

persons.name: Barket
persons.context: Issued a response to the Stemheim report on January 16, 2020.

persons.name: Judge Karas
persons.context: A judge to whom BB wrote a letter complaining about prison conditions and threats against Nicholas Tartaglione.

persons.name: Ross
persons.context: Mentioned in relation to a letter dated January 8, 2020.

connections.description: Were cellmates at MCC. Epstein claimed Tartaglione assaulted him; Tartaglione found a note allegedly left by Epstein.
BB is an attorney who visited Tartaglione in prison, advised him on the note, and communicated with the press on his behalf.
BB consulted TR about the note and press strategy. TR disagreed with some of BB's decisions and raised concerns about the note's authenticity.
BB called JW to inform him he would be receiving a document (the note) from Nicholas Tartaglione during a visit.
JW visited Tartaglione in prison and received the note from him.
BS visited Tartaglione, who told him about a letter left in a book.

events.title: Epstein Booked into MCC
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was booked into the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC).

events.title: Epstein Found Unresponsive in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found unresponsive in his cell with cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione. Epstein claimed Tartaglione assaulted him. Both were removed from the cell, a search was executed, and Epstein was placed on suicide watch.

events.title: Note Discovery Period Begins
events.description: Sometime between July 23 and July 27, Nicholas Tartaglione found a note allegedly left by Jeffrey Epstein in a book.

events.title: Note Transferred to Attorney
events.description: BB visited Nicholas Tartaglione, who told him about the note. BB instructed Tartaglione to give it to the next lawyer visiting. JW visited later that day and received the note.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was removed from suicide watch and placed in a different cell in the Special Housing Unit (SHU), not with Nicholas Tartaglione.

events.title: Tartaglione Cleared
events.description: Nicholas Tartaglione was cleared of causing Jeffrey Epstein's injuries.

events.title: Epstein Found Dead
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell at MCC.

events.title: CNN Report on BB Statements
events.description: CNN reported quotes from attorney BB, including that the notion Epstein was murdered is "ridiculous," and that MCC guards threatened Nicholas Tartaglione. BB also wrote to Judge Karas about prison conditions.

events.title: BB on 60 Minutes
events.description: Attorney BB appeared on 60 Minutes, stating Nicholas Tartaglione had information on prison conditions and Epstein's suicide. The show featured a note, and BB authenticated it.

keyFacts: A contraband phone was seized from Nicholas Tartaglione on July 3, 2019, prior to Epstein's incarceration.
Jeffrey Epstein claimed his cellmate Nicholas Tartaglione assaulted him on July 23, 2019, an allegation Tartaglione denied and was later cleared of.

A note allegedly written by Jeffrey Epstein was discovered by Nicholas Tartaglione in a book between July 23-27, 2019, and became a subject of legal and media attention, with concerns raised about its authenticity.
Jeffrey Epstein was found dead in his cell on August 10, 2019, after having been removed from suicide watch on July 29, 2019.
Attorney BB publicly stated the idea Epstein was murdered was "ridiculous" and alleged MCC guards threatened Nicholas Tartaglione to stop him from talking about prison conditions and Epstein's death.
